citation.article-title: Geomicrobium halophilum gen. nov., sp. nov., a moderately halophilic and alkaliphilic bacterium isolated from soil
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Geomicrobium halophilum sp. nov.
Geomicrobium halophilum (ha.lo.phi′lum. Gr. n. hals halos salt; Gr. adj. philos loving; N.L. neut. adj. halophilum salt-loving).
Exhibits the following characteristics in addition to those given in the genus description.
Colonies formed on agar are approximately 1.0–1.5 mm in diameter, brown, opaque and stained the surrounding agar brown.
Growth occurs in 5–25 % (w/v) NaCl, with maximum growth at 10–15 % (w/v) NaCl.
No growth occurs in the absence of NaCl, but cells do not die.
Growth occurs at pH 6.0–10.0, with optimum growth at pH 8.5–9.0.
Temperature range for growth is 20–40 °C, with optimum growth at 30 °C.

Cellobiose, glycerol, lactose, d-mannitol, raffinose, trehalose, d-sorbitol and sucrose can be utilized as sole carbon sources; l-arabinose, d-fructose, d-galactose, d-glucose, maltose, d-mannose, ribose and d-xylose cannot be utilized.

Acid is produced from d-glucose, glycerol, d-sorbitol and sucrose, but not from l-arabinose, cellobiose, d-fructose, d-galactose, lactose, maltose, d-mannitol, d-mannose, raffinose, ribose, trehalose or d-xylose.

Sensitive to ampicillin (50 μg per disc), bacitracin (25 μg per disc), chloramphenicol (25 μg per disc), erythromycin (25 μg per disc), gentamicin (50 μg per disc), novobiocin (25 μg per disc), penicillin G (25 μg per disc), rifampicin (50 μg per disc), streptomycin (100 μg per disc), tetracycline (50 μg per disc) and vancomycin (25 μg per disc); resistant to anisomycin (50 μg per disc), kanamycin (50 μg per disc), neomycin (25 μg per disc) and pravastatin (50 μg per disc).
Ornithine decarboxylase-positive, but arginine decarboxylase- and lysine decarboxylase-negative.
Casein and gelatin are hydrolysed; starch, pullulan, Tween 80, tributyrin, DNA, hippurate, aesculin, urea, tyrosine, xanthine and hypoxanthine are not hydrolysed.
Indole and H2S are not produced.
Reduction of nitrate and gas formation are not observed.
The phospholipids are diphosphatidylglycerol and phosphatidylglycerol.
The type strain is strain BH1T (=JCM 15647T=DSM 21769T), isolated from ordinary soil from a forest in a campus of Toyo University, Kawagoe City, Saitama Prefecture, Japan.
